2007-08-19 }} BYU offers programs in [[liberal arts]], [[engineering]], [[agriculture]], [[management]], and [[law]]. The university is broadly organized into 11 colleges or schools at its main Provo campus, with certain colleges and divisions defining their own admission standards. The university also administers two satellite campuses, one in [[BYU Jerusalem Center|Jerusalem]] and one in [[Salt Lake City]], while its parent organization, the [[Church Educational System]], sponsors sister schools in [[Brigham Young UniversityâHawaii|Hawaii]] and [[Brigham Young UniversityâIdaho|Idaho]]. The university's primary focus is on [[undergraduate education]], but it also has 68 [[master's degree|master's]] and 25 [[doctoral degree]] programs. BYU's athletic teams compete in [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] and are collectively known as the [[BYU Cougars]]. They are [[NCAA Division I FBS independent schools|independent]] in football, with other sports in the [[West Coast Conference]] and [[Mountain Pacific Sports Federation|MPSF]], and have won ten national championships. == History == {{Main|History of Brigham Young University}} [[File:BrighamYoung1.jpg|thumb|right|[[Brigham Young]], the school's namesake]] === Early days === Brigham Young University's origin can be traced back to 1862 when a man named [[Warren Newton Dusenberry|Warren Dusenberry]] started a Provo school in a prominent adobe building called Cluff Hall, which was located in the northeast corner of 200 East and 200 North.{{cite news |first = D. Robert |last = Carter |url = http://old.heraldextra.com/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=53358 |title = The hall the Cluffs built |work = The Daily Herald |date= 2005-04-24}} On October 16, 1875, [[Brigham Young]], then [[President of the Church|President]] of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]], personally purchased the Lewis Building after previously hinting that a school would be built in Draper, Utah in 1867.{{cite web| title=BYU: The "almost" college of Draper, Utah| url=http://www.russpage.net/byu-the-almost-college-of-draper-utah/}} Hence, October 16, 1875 is commonly held as BYU's founding date.{{cite web| title =Brigham Young High School History: 1869 to 1903 - The Founding Years | publisher =Brigham Young High School| url =http://abc.eznettools.net/D300015/X329586/History/HistoryDecades/From1869to1903.html| accessdate = 2007-08-19 }} Said Young about his vision: "I hope to see an Academy established in Provo... at which the children of the Latter-day Saints can receive a good education unmixed with the pernicious atheistic influences that are found in so many of the higher schools of the country." The school broke off from the [[University of Deseret]] and became ''Brigham Young Academy'',{{cite news |first = Sarah |last = Bills |url = http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/43900 |title = Warren Dusenberry (1875 - 1876) |work = BYU NewsNet |date= 2003-04-16}} with classes commencing on January 3, 1876. Warren Dusenberry served as interim principal of the school for several months until April 1876 when Brigham Young's choice for principal arrivedâa German immigrant named [[Karl G. Maeser|Karl Maeser]]. The school did not become a university, however, until the end of [[Benjamin Cluff|Benjamin Cluff, Jr's]] term at the helm of the institution. At that time, the school was also still privately supported by members of the community and was not absorbed and sponsored officially by the LDS Church until July 18, 1896.{{cite web| title =From 1903 to 1920 ~ A High School Within a University| work =Brigham Young High School History| publisher =Brigham Young High School| year= 2007| url =http://www.byhigh.org/History/HistoryDecades/From1903to1920.html| accessdate = 2007-08-20 }} A series of odd managerial decisions by Cluff led to his demotion; however, in his last official act, he proposed to the Board that the Academy be named "Brigham Young University". The suggestion received a large amount of opposition, many members of the Board saying that the school wasn't large enough to be a university, but the decision ultimately passed. One opponent to the decision, Anthon H. Lund, later said, "I hope their head will grow big enough for their hat." In 1903, Brigham Young Academy was dissolved, and was replaced by two institutions: [[Brigham Young High School]], and Brigham Young University.[http://www.byhigh.org/History/HistoryDecades/From1903to1920.html History of Brigham Young High School from 1903 to 1920] (The BY High School class of 1907 was ultimately responsible for the [[hillside letters|famous giant "Y"]] that is to this day [[Y Mountain|embedded on a mountain]] near campus.) The Board elected [[George H. Brimhall]] as the new President of BYU. He had not received a high school education until he was forty. Nevertheless, he was an excellent orator and organizer. Under his tenure in 1904 the new Brigham Young University bought {{convert|17|acre|m2}} of land from Provo called "Temple Hill". After some controversy among locals over BYU's purchase of this property, construction began in 1909 on the first building on the current campus, the Karl G. Maeser Memorial.{{cite web| title =History| work =About BYU| publisher =BYU.edu| year= 2007| url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/about/default.aspx?content=history| accessdate = 2007-08-20}} Brimhall also presided over the University during a brief crisis involving the theory of evolution. The religious nature of the school seemed at the time to collide with this scientific theory. [[Joseph F. Smith]], President of the Church, settled the question for a time by asking that evolution not be taught at the school. A few have described the school at this time as nothing more than a "religious seminary". However, many of its graduates at this time would go on to great success and renown in their fields. === Expansion === [[File:Smoot Building.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The Abraham O. Smoot Administration Building, the main administration building on the Provo campus]] [[Franklin S. Harris]] was appointed President of the University in 1921. He was the first President of BYU to have a doctoral degree. Harris made several important changes to the school, reorganizing it into a true University, whereas before, its organization had remnants of the Academy days. At the beginning of his tenure, the school was not officially recognized as a university by any accreditation organization. By the end of his term, the school was accredited under all major accrediting organizations at the time. He was eventually replaced by President [[Howard S. McDonald]], who received his doctorate from the [[University of California, Berkeley|University of California]]. When he first received the position, the [[Second World War]] had just ended, and thousands of students were flooding into BYU. By the end of his stay, the school had grown nearly five times to an enrollment of 5,440 students. The University did not have the facilities to handle such a large influx, so he bought part of an Air Force Base in [[Ogden, Utah]] and rebuilt it to house some of the students. The next President, [[Ernest L. Wilkinson]], also oversaw a period of intense growth, as the school adopted an accelerated building program. Wilkinson was responsible for the building of over eighty structures on the campus, many of which still stand to this day.{{cite web| title =Ernest L. Wilkinson| work =Presidents| publisher =BYU.edu| year= 2007| url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/wilkinson.aspx| accessdate = 2007-08-20 }} During his tenure, the student body increased six times, making BYU the largest private school at the time. The quality of the students also increased, leading to higher educational standards at the school.{{cite web| last =Wilkinson| first =Ernest L.| title =Highlights in the Ninety-Nine-Year History of BYU| publisher =Brigham Young University Press| date= 1974-10-10| url =http://speeches.byu.edu/reader/reader.php?id=6112| accessdate =2007-08-19}} Finally, President Wilkinson reorganized the LDS church units on campus, with ten [[Stake (Latter Day Saints)|stakes]] and over 100 [[Ward (LDS Church)|wards]] being added during his administration. [[File:BYU Campus North.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Overlooking North Campus]] [[Dallin H. Oaks]] replaced Wilkinson as President in 1971. Oaks continued the expansion of his predecessor, adding a law school and proposing plans for a new School of Management. During his administration, a new library was also added, doubling the library space on campus.{{cite web| title =Dallin H. Oaks| work =Presidents| publisher =BYU.edu| year= 2007| url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/oaks.aspx| accessdate = 2007-08-20}} [[Jeffrey R. Holland]] followed as President in 1980, encouraging a combination of educational excellence and religious faith at the university. He believed that one of the school's greatest strengths was its religious nature and that this should be taken advantage of rather than hidden. During his administration, the university added a campus in Jerusalem, now called the [[BYU Jerusalem Center]]. In 1989, Holland was replaced by [[Rex E. Lee]].{{cite web| title =Jeffrey R. Holland| work =Presidents| publisher =BYU.edu| year= 2007| url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/holland.aspx| accessdate = 2007-08-20}} Lee was responsible for the Benson Science Building and the Museum of Art on campus.{{cite web| title =Rex E. Lee| work =Presidents| publisher =BYU.edu| year= 2007| url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/lee.aspx| accessdate = 2007-08-20}} A cancer victim, Lee is memorialized annually at BYU during a cancer fundraiser called the Rex Lee Run.{{cite web| title =Rex Lee Run| url =http://rexleerun.byu.edu/honorinfo.php| accessdate = 2007-08-20 }} Lee was replaced shortly before his death in 1996 by [[Merrill J. Bateman| work =Presidents| publisher =BYU.edu| year= 2007| url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/bateman.aspx| accessdate = 2007-08-20}} Bateman was responsible for the building of 36 new buildings for the University both on and off campus, including the expansion of the Harold B. Lee Library from 1996-1999. He was also one of several key college leaders who brought about the creation of the [[Mountain West Conference]], which BYU's athletics program joinedâBYU previously participating in the [[Western Athletic Conference]]. A [[BYU TV|BYU satellite TV network]] also opened in 2000 under his leadership. Bateman was also president during the [[September 11th attacks]] in 2001. The planes crashed on a Tuesday, mere hours before the weekly devotional normally held at BYU. Previous plans for the devotional were altered, as Bateman led the student body in a prayer for peace.{{cite web| last =Carter| first =Jane| coauthors =Marla Sowards| title =President leaves mark on campus| publisher =BYU Newsnet| date= 2003-04-16| url =http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/43904| accessdate = 2007-08-20 }} Bateman was followed by [[Cecil O. Samuelson]] in 2003, who is the current president.{{cite web|last= Bardsley|first=Ann Jardine| title =BYU's Utah Man|work = Continuum| publisher =Utah.edu| year= 2003| url =http://www.alumni.utah.edu/continuum/fall03/byu.htm| accessdate = 2008-06-14}} == Academics == === Admissions and demographics === BYU accepted 68% of the 10,409 people who applied for admission in the summer term and fall semester of 2009.{{cite web| title =Admission:Entrance Averages| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://saas.byu.edu/admissionsServices/schoolRelations/pf/admissions/entrance_averages.htm| accessdate = 2007-07-25 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071101024609/http://saas.byu.edu/admissionsServices/schoolRelations/pf/admissions/entrance_averages.htm |archivedate = November 1, 2007|deadurl=yes}} The average ACT score and GPA for these admitted students was 28.2 and 3.8, respectively. ''U.S. News and World Report'' describes BYU's selectivity as being "more selective" and compares it with such universities as the [[University of Texas]] and [[The Ohio State University]].{{cite web| title =Brigham Young UniversityâProvo| publisher =U.S. News and World Report| year= 2007| url =http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/college/directory/brief/drglance_3670_brief.php| accessdate =2007-07-25 }}{{cite web| title =University of Texas-Austin| publisher =U.S. News and World Report| url =http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/college/directory/brief/drglance_3658_brief.php| accessdate = 2007-07-25 }} In the case of University of Texas-Austin ("UT"), BYU appears to be more selective in some regards, with 27% of admitted freshmen having ACT scores over 30, as compared with 23% for UT.{{cite web| title =The University of Texas at Austin| publisher =Peterson's| url =http://education.yahoo.com/college/facts/9414.html| accessdate = 2007-07-25 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070703131131/http://education.yahoo.com/college/facts/9414.html |archivedate = July 3, 2007}}{{cite web| title =Ohio State University-Columbus| publisher =U.S. News and World Report| url =http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/college/directory/brief/drglance_6883_brief.php| accessdate = 2007-07-25 }} In addition, BYU is ranked 26th in colleges with the most freshman [[National Merit Scholarship Program|Merit Scholars]], with 88 in 2006.The Chronicle of Higher Education, August 31, 2007. For the past two years, BYU outranked every university in the country including [[Harvard University]] for the percentage of accepted applicants that go on to enroll (78% vs. 76% for [[Harvard]]).[http://www.usnews.com/articles/education/best-colleges/2010/03/05/brigham-young-university-is-nations-most-popular-national-university.html USnews.com] [[File:Harold B. Lee Library.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The [[Harold B. Lee Library]] is consistently ranked among the top ten in the nation, with a #1 ranking in 2004 by ''[[The Princeton Review]]''.]] Students from every state in the U.S. and from many foreign countries attend BYU. (In the 2005-6 academic year, there were 2,396 foreign students, or 8% of enrollment.) Slightly more than 98% of these students are active members of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]]. In 2006, 12.6% of the student body reported themselves as ethnic minorities, mostly Asians, Pacific islanders and Hispanics.{{cite web |url=http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=135 |title=About BYU - Demographics |accessdate=2008-08-01 |publisher=BYU.edu}} === Graduation honors === {{see also|Brigham Young University Honors Program}} Undergraduate students may qualify for graduation honors. ''[[Brigham Young University Honors Program#University Honors|University Honors]]'' is the highest distinction BYU awards its graduates.{{cite web |url=http://ccc.byu.edu/honors |title=Honors |accessdate=2010-01-21 |publisher=Brigham Young University}} {{dead link| date=June 2010 | bot=DASHBot}} Administered by the [[Brigham Young University Honors Program|Honors Program]], the distinction requires students to complete an honors curriculum requirement, a Great Works requirement, an Advanced Languages requirement, a service requirement, an honors thesis requirement, a graduation portfolio that summarizes the student's honors experiencesâall while maintaining at least a 3.5 GPA. The university also awards [[Latin honors|Latin scholastic distinctions]] separately from the Honors Program: ''summa cum laude'' (top 1 percent), ''magna cum laude'' (top 5 percent), and ''cum laude'' (top 10 percent).{{cite web |url=http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2009-2010ucat/GeneralInfo/Graduation.php#LatinScholDistinctions |title=BYU Graduation Honors |accessdate=2010-01-21 |publisher=Brigham Young University}} The university additionally recognizes [[Phi Kappa Phi]] graduation honors. === Rankings === {{Infobox US university ranking | ARWU_W = 303â401 | ARWU_N = 135â162 | Forbes = 136 | THES_W = 501â600 | USNWR_NU = 71 | Wamo_NU = 68 }} For 2012, ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' ranked BYU as #71 for national universities in the United States.{{cite web| title =America's Best Colleges 2012| publisher =U.S. News and World Report| date= 200y| url =http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/rankings/national-universities/spp%2B50/page+2| accessdate = 2011-10-22 }} ''The Princeton Review'' has ranked BYU the best value for college in 2007,{{cite web| title =Texas State named Best Western College for 2008| publisher =Texas State University| url =http://www.txstate.edu/about/best-value.html| accessdate = 2007-08-30 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070804173258/http://www.txstate.edu/about/best-value.html |archivedate = August 4, 2007|deadurl=yes}} and its [[Harold B. For example, BYU's [http://ic.byu.edu/ International Cinema], featuring films in several languages, is the largest and longest-running university-run foreign film program in the country.{{cite web| title =About Us| work =BYU International Cinema| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://ic.byu.edu/about_us.php| accessdate = 2007-08-30 }} As already noted, BYU also offers an intensive foreign language living experience, the Foreign Language Student Residence. This is an on-campus apartment complex where students commit to only speak their foreign language of choice while in their apartments. Each apartment has at least one native speaker to ensure correct language usage.{{cite web| title =Room Options| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://www.byu.edu/oncampushousing/rooms.html| accessdate = 2007-08-30 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070822224947/http://www.byu.edu/oncampushousing/rooms.html |archivedate = August 22, 2007|deadurl=yes}} === Academic freedom issues === {{Main|Academic freedom at Brigham Young University}} In 1992, the university drafted a new Statement on Academic Freedom,{{cite web| title = Statement on Academic Freedom at BYU| publisher = BYU| date = 1992-09-14| url = http://fc.byu.edu/opages/reference/academicfreedom.htm| accessdate = 2008-01-11}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} specifying that limitations may be placed upon "expression with students or in public that: (1) contradicts or opposes, rather than analyzes or discusses, fundamental Church doctrine or policy; (2) deliberately attacks or derides the Church or its general leaders; or (3) violates the [[Brigham Young University Honor Code|Honor Code]] because the expression is dishonest, illegal, unchaste, profane, or unduly disrespectful of others." These restrictions have caused some controversy as several professors have been disciplined according to the new rule. The [[American Association of University Professors]] has claimed that "infringements on academic freedom are distressingly common and that the climate for academic freedom is distressingly poor."{{cite web| title = Academic Freedom and Tenure |date = 1997-09-01| publisher = [[American Association of University Professors]] | url = http://www.aaup.org/NR/rdonlyres/27EB0A08-8D25-4415-9E55-8081CC874AC5/0/Brigham.pdf | accessdate = 2008-05-25 |format=PDF}} The new rules have not affected BYU's accreditation, as the university's chosen accrediting body allows "religious colleges and universities to place limitations on academic freedom so long as they publish those limitations candidly", according to associate academic vice president Jim Gordon.{{cite web| title = The Issue of Academic Freedom: An Interview with Jim Gordon | publisher = ''BYU Magazine'' | year = 1997| url = http://magazine.byu.edu/?act=view&a=664| accessdate = 2008-01-11 }} The [[American Association of University Professors|AAUP]]'s concern was not with restrictions on the faculty member's religious expression but with a failure, as alleged by the faculty member and AAUP, that the restrictions had not been adequately specified in advance by BYU: "The AAUP requires that any doctrinal limitations on academic freedom be laid out clearly in writing. Slade| title = Sunday at School | work = BYU Magazine | publisher = Brigham Young University| pages = 26â31| date = Spring 2007}} === Museums === [[File:MOA North entrance.JPG|thumb|right|[[Brigham Young University Museum of Art|Museum of Art]] north entrance]] The campus is home to several museums containing exhibits from many different fields of study. BYU's [[Brigham Young University Museum of Art|Museum of Art]], for example, is one of the largest and most attended art museums in the Mountain West. This Museum aids in academic pursuits of students at BYU via research and study of the artworks in its collection. The Museum is also open to the general public and provides educational programming.{{cite web| title =About the Museum| work =Brigham Young University Museum of Art| publisher =Brigham Young University| date= 2006-09-28| url =http://moa.byu.edu/index.php?id=50http://moa.byu.edu/index.php?id=50| accessdate = 2007-08-21 }} [[Brigham Young University Museum of Peoples and Cultures|The Museum of Peoples and Cultures]] is a museum of archaeology and ethnology. It focuses on native cultures and artifacts of the Great Basin, American Southwest, Mesoamerica, Peru, and Polynesia. Home to more than 40,000 artifacts and 50,000 photographs, it documents BYU's archaeological research.{{cite web| title =Collections| work =Museum of Peoples and Cultures| publisher =Brigham Young University| date= 2008-07-12| url =http://mpc.byu.edu/Research/Collections.dhtml| accessdate = 2008-07-12 }} The Museum of Paleontology was built in 1976 to display the many fossils found by BYU's Dr. James A. Jensen. It holds many artifacts from the [[Jurassic Period]] (210-140 million years ago), and is one the top five collections in the world of fossils from that time period. It has been featured in magazines, newspapers, and on television internationally. The museum receives about 25,000 visitors every year.{{cite web| title =Museum Information| work =BYU Earth Science Museum| publisher =Brigham Young University| date= 2006-10-26| url =http://cpms.byu.edu/ESM/information.html| accessdate = 2007-08-21 }}{{cite web| title =On Display at the Museum| work =BYU Earth Science Museum| publisher =Brigham Young University| date= 2006-10-26| url =http://cpms.byu.edu/ESM/index.html| accessdate = 2007-08-21 }} The [[Monte L. Bean Life Science Museum]] was formed in 1978. It features several forms of plant and animal life on display and available for research by students and scholars.{{cite web| title =Museum Description| work =Monte L. Bean Museum of Life Science| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://mlbean.byu.edu/home/page/Description.aspx| accessdate = 2007-08-21 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070701001829/http://mlbean.byu.edu/home/page/Description.aspx |archivedate = July 1, 2007|deadurl=yes}} The campus also houses several performing arts facilities. The de Jong Concert Hall seats 1282 people and is named for [[Gerrit de Jong Jr.]] The Pardoe Theatre is named for T. Earl and Kathryn Pardoe. Students use its stage in a variety of theatre experiments, as well as for Pardoe Series performances. It seats 500 people, and has quite a large stage with a [[proscenium]] opening of 19 by {{convert|55|ft|m}}.{{cite web| title =Facilities| work =College of Fine Arts and Communications| publisher =Brigham Young University| date= 2007-07-27| url =http://tma.byu.edu/index.php?id=609| accessdate = 2007-08-21 }} The Margetts Theatre was named for Philip N. Margetts, a prominent Utah theatre figure. A smaller, [[black box theater]], it allows a variety of seating and staging formats. It seats 125, and measures 30 by {{convert|50|ft|m}}. The Nelke Theatre, named for one of BYU's first drama teachers, is used largely for instruction in experimental theater. It seats 280. === Student housing === {{main|List of Brigham Young University residence halls}} [[File:ForeignLanguageHousing.JPG|thumb|left|Foreign Language Student Residence, where students commit to speak only their language of study]] Single students have four options for on-campus housing: Heritage Halls, Helaman Halls, Wyview Park, and the FLSR. Married students can live in Wymount Terrace. Heritage Halls is a twenty-four building housing complex on campus which offers apartment-style living. The halls house both male and female students, divided by gender into separate buildings. Each building has ten to fourteen units capable of housing six people each. Helaman Halls is a slightly newer complex which has recently undergone a 12 year renovation spanning 1991 and through 2004.{{cite web| last =Chamberlin| first =Sarah | title =A new home: Helaman Halls construction completed | publisher =BYU Newsnet| date= 2003-09-30| url =http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/45808| accessdate = 2007-08-21 }} Helaman Halls is a seven building (seventh added in the summer of 2010), dormitory style living area. Residents share a room (larger than Heritage Halls) with one other resident, but do not have their own kitchen and use shared bathrooms. Residents are required to have a meal plan, and eat at the newly remodeled Commons at the Cannon Center.[http://www.byu.edu/oncampushousing/rooms/room_options.shtml#helaman BYU.edu] Wyview Park was originally built for families in 1996, but this changed in 2006 when the complex began housing single students in order to counteract loss of singles' housing in other areas.{{cite web| last =Schaerr| first =Stephanie | title =Single Students Move in to Wyview| publisher =BYU Newsnet| date= 2006-09-05| url =http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/60723| accessdate = 2007-08-21 }} Wyview Park has 30 buildings that offer apartment-style living for students, along with the option for shared or single rooms. The Foreign Language Student Residence complex has twenty-five apartments where students speak exclusively in a selected foreign language. The immersion experience is available in nine languages, and students are accompanied by a native resident throughout the year to enhance the experience.{{cite web| title =BYU Housing - FLSR Info| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://flsr.byu.edu/about.php| accessdate = 2007-08-21 }} Married students can house in Wymount Terrace, which contains a total of 462 apartments in 24 buildings.{{cite web| title =Wymount Terrace, 1960s| work =BYU Campus Photographs| publisher =Brigham young University| url =http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=/BYUPhotos&CISOPTR=692&CISOBOX=1&REC=3| accessdate = 2007-08-21 }} Branches of the [[BYU Creamery]] provide basic food and general grocery products for students living in Heritage Halls, Helaman, Wymount, Wyview, and the FLSR. Helaman Halls is also served by a central cafeteria called the Cannon Center.{{cite web| title =Room Options| work =On-Campus Housing| publisher =Brigham young University| url =http://www.byu.edu/oncampushousing/rooms.html#heritage_halls| accessdate = 2007-08-21 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070822224947/http://www.byu.edu/oncampushousing/rooms.html |archivedate = August 22, 2007|deadurl=yes}} The creamery, begun in 1949, has become a BYU tradition and is also frequented by visitors to the university and members of the community.{{cite web| last =Moss| first =Michael| title =Sweet Creams: BYU Creamery a Campus Landmark Since 1949| date= 2007-05-30| url =http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/64478| accessdate = 2007-08-21 }} It was the first on-campus full-service grocery store in the country.{{cite web| last =Woodland| first =Mark| title =Creamery on Ninth declared 'Good Neighbor'| publisher =BYU Newsnet| date= 2006-07-26| url =http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/60499| accessdate = 2007-08-21 }} === Sustainability === BYU has designated energy conservation, products and materials, recycling, site planning and building design, student involvement, transportation, water conservation, and zero waste events as top priority categories in which to further its efforts to be an environmentally sustainable campus. The university has stated that "we have a responsibility to be wise stewards of the earth and its resources."{{cite web | title =Y Facts - Sustainability | publisher =Brigham Young University | url =http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewcategory.aspx?id=82 | accessdate = 2009-06-08 }} BYU is working to increase the energy efficiency of its buildings by installing various speed drives on all pumps and fans, replacing incandescent lighting with fluorescent lighting, retrofitting campus buildings with low-E reflective glass, and upgraded roof insulation to prevent heat loss.{{cite web | title =Energy Conservation | publisher =Brigham Young University | url =http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=256 | accessdate = 2009-06-08 }} The student groups BYU Recycles, Eco-Response, and BYU Earth educate students, faculty, staff, and administrators about how the campus can decrease its environmental impact. BYU Recycles spearheaded the recent campaign to begin recycling plastics, which the university did after a year of student campaigning.{{cite web | title =Student Involvement | publisher =Brigham Young University | url =http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=260 | accessdate = 2009-06-08 }}{{cite web | title =BYU Newsnet - Going Toward the Green | publisher =Brigham Young University | url =http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/72130 | accessdate = 2009-06-08 }} == Performing arts == [[File:BYUclarillon.jpg|right|thumb|The [[BYU Centennial Carillon]] stands at the north end of campus.]] === Dance === The [[BYU Ballroom Dance Company]] is known as one of the best formation ballroom dance teams in the world,{{cite web|title = BYU Ballroom Dance Company| publisher = Dance.com| date = 2006-01-20| url = http://www.rounddance.com/artman/publish/cat_index_35.shtml| accessdate = 2008-03-12}} having won the U.S. National Formation Dance Championship every year since 1982.{{cite web| last = Benjamin | first = Bob | title = BYU Ballroom Dance| publisher = Dance.com| date = 2006-01-20| url = http://www.rounddance.com/artman/publish/BYU_Ballroom_Dance_Company_20060120.shtml| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} BYU's Ballroom dance team has won first place in Latin or Standard (or both) many times when they have competed at the [[Blackpool Dance Festival]], they were the first U.S. team to win the formation championships at the famed British Championships in Blackpool England in 1972 .{{cite web| title = Brigham Young University Ballroom Dance Company| publisher = Midsummer Arts Faire| url = http://www.artsfaire.org/byu_dancers.html| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} The NDCA National [[DanceSport]] championships have been held at BYU for several years, and BYU holds dozens of ballroom dance classes each semester and is consequently the largest collegiate ballroom dance program in the world. In addition, BYU has a number of other notable dance teams and programs. These teams range from Theater Ballet to the International Folk Dance Ensemble. BYU boasts one of the largest dance departments in the nation. Many students from all different majors across campus participate in various dance classes each semester. === Music === The [[Young Ambassadors]] is a song and dance performing group with a 50-year history at BYU. Prior to 1970 the group was known as Curtain Time USA. In the 1960s their world tour stops included [[Lebanon]], [[Jordan]], and [[Iraq]]. The group first performed as the Young Ambasadors at [[Expo '70]] in [[Japan]], and has since performed in over 56 nations. The royalty of [[Thailand]] and [[Jordan]], along with persons of high office in countries such as [[India]], have been among their audiences.{{cite web| title = Young Ambassadors| publisher = BYU| url = http://pam.byu.edu/SimilarPage.asp?title=Young%20Ambassadors| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} [[File:BYU Concert Choir with Poppies.jpg|thumb|left|350px|The [[BYU Choirs|Concert Choir]] in performance]] BYU also has a strong emphasis on [[jazz]] music with the premiere performing group ''Synthesis'' leading the way. ''Synthesis'' has toured in over 30 countries and performed at some of the biggest [[jazz festival]]s in the world, namely [[Montreux]] (Switzerland), [[Pori]] (Finland), [[Copenhagen]] (Denmark), [[Umbria]] (Italy), [[IAJE]] (International Association of Jazz Educators) and many others. ''Synthesis'' also performed at the [[Expo 2000|2000 World Expo]] in [[Hannover, Germany]]. Many of ''Synthesis''' alumni have gone on to perform and record nationally and internationally as well as teach at prestigious [[universities]] nationwide. BYU offers degree programs in [[Music theory|Music]], [[Music Education]], Music Performance, Jazz Studies and many more. BYU's Wind Symphony and Chamber Orchestra have toured many countries including [[Denmark]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Russia]], the [[British Isles]], and [[Central Europe]]. The Symphonic Band is also an [[Musical ensemble|ensemble]] dedicated to developing the musician, but with a less strenuous focus on [[performance]]. Additionally, BYU has a [[marching band]] program called the Cougar Marching Band.{{cite web| title = BYU Bands| publisher = BYU| date = 2006-05-11| url = http://bands.byu.edu/information/general_info.html| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} BYU has a choral program with over 500 members. The four BYU auditioned [[BYU Choirs|choirs]] include the 40-member [[BYU Choirs|BYU Singers]], the 90-member [[BYU Choirs|BYU Concert Choir]], the 200-member [[BYU Choirs|BYU Men's Chorus]] (the largest male collegiate choir in the U.S.{{cite web| title = Brigham Young University Men's Chorus| publisher = BYU| year = 2008| url = http://menschorus.byu.edu| accessdate = 2008-01-21}}), and the 190-member [[BYU Choirs|BYU Women's Chorus]].{{cite web| title = BYU Concert Choir| publisher = BYU| url = http://concertchoir.byu.edu/| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} Both the BYU Men's Chorus and BYU Singers have toured across the [[United States]] and around the globe. Each of the four groups has recorded several times under BYU's label ''[[Tantara Records]]''.{{cite web| title = Tantara Records| url = https://tantararecords.com/| accessdate = 2008-05-26}} == Athletics == {{Main|BYU Cougars}} [[File:BYA Football Champions 1896.png|thumb|right|The school's first football team won the regional championship in 1896.]] BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams.[http://www.byucougars.com/athletic_department/quick_facts.jsp Athletic Department fact sheet] Nineteen of these teams have played mainly in the [[Mountain West Conference]] since its inception in 1999. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the [[Western Athletic Conference]]. All teams are named the "Cougars", and [[Cosmo the Cougar]] has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the [[The Cougar Song (BYU)|Cougar Fight Song]]. Because many of its players serve on full time missions for two years, BYU's athletes are often older on average than other school's players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. This has caused minor controversy, but is largely recognized as not lending the school any significant advantage, since players receive no athletic and little physical training during their missions.{{cite web| last = Crain| first = Nate | title = The Myth of the BYU Missionary Advantage| publisher = Scout.com| date = 2005-06-10| url = http://coloradostate.scout.com/a.z?s=132&p=2&c=386324| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} BYU has also received attention from sports networks for refusal to play games on Sunday, as well as [[2010â11 BYU Cougars men's basketball team#Davies controversy|expelling players]] due to honor code violations.{{cite web| last = Jackson| first = Lisa Ann | title = Setting things straight| publisher = BYU Magazine| url = http://magazine.byu.edu/?act=view&a=202| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} BYU football will start the 2011 college football season as an independent. Other sports will leave the MWC and compete in the [[West Coast Conference]]. Swimming and diving will join the Men's Volleyball Program in the [[Mountain Pacific Sports Federation]].{{cite web| last = Tittle| first = Duff | title = BYU Swimming and Diving to join the Mountain Pacific Sports Federation| publisher=BYUCougars.com| date=2010-10-18| url=http://www.byucougars.com/Filing.jsp?ID=14530| accessdate = 2010-10-08}} The Cougars will also compete in the MPSF for indoor track and field on both the men's and women's side. For outdoor track and field, the Cougars will become an Independent.{{cite web| last = Rothlisburger| first = Jen | title = BYU Announces New Direction for Men's and Women's Track Teams| publisher=BYUCougars.com| date=2011-03-16| url=http://www.byucougars.com/Filing.jsp?ID=15308| accessdate = 2011-03-16}} Softball will return to the Western Athletic Conference.{{cite web| last = Tittle| first = Duff | title = BYU Softball to Join WAC| publisher=BYUCougars.com| date=2011-01-27| url=http://www.byucougars.com/Filing.jsp?ID=14986| accessdate = 2011-01-27}} == Student life == {{Main|Student life at Brigham Young University}} === LDS atmosphere === {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 25%;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: left;" | "The mission of [BYU] is to assist individuals in their quest for perfection and eternal life. That assistance should provide a period of intensive learning in a stimulating setting where a commitment to excellence is expected and the full realization of human potential is pursued...." |- | style="text-align: left;" | â BYU Mission Statement |} BYU's stated mission "is to assist individuals in their quest for perfection and [[Exaltation (LDS Church)|eternal life]]." BYU is thus considered by its leaders to be at heart a religious institution, wherein, ideally, religious and secular education are interwoven in a way that encourages the highest standards in both areas.{{cite web| last = Peer| first = Larry H. | title = Beethoven's Kiss: On the Odd Reasons for Brigham Young's Excellent University| work = BYU Speeches| publisher = BYU| date = 2003-12-02| url = http://speeches.byu.edu/reader/reader.php?id=4530| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} This weaving of the secular and the religious aspects of a religious university goes back as far as Brigham Young himself, who told Karl G. Maeser when the Church purchased the school: "I want you to remember that you ought not to teach even the alphabet or the multiplication tables without the [[Holy Spirit#Latter Day Saints|Spirit of God]]."{{cite web| title = Teaching with the Spirit:A Broader Definition| work = Focus on Faculty| date = Winter 1993| url = http://fc.byu.edu/opages/reference/newslet/v1n1.pdf| accessdate = 2008-01-21|format=PDF |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080228100026/http://fc.byu.edu/opages/reference/newslet/v1n1.pdf |archivedate = 2008-02-28}} BYU has been considered by some Latter-day Saints, as well as some university and Church leaders, to be "The Lord's university". This phrase is used in reference to the school's mission as an "ambassador" to the world for the LDS Church and thus, for [[Jesus#Christian views|Jesus Christ]].{{cite web| last = Rector| first = Hartman Jr. | title = Go Forth to Serve| work = BYU Speeches| publisher = BYU| date = 1975-03-25| url = http://speeches.byu.edu/reader/reader.php?id=6088| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} In the past, some students and faculty have expressed dissatisfaction with this nickname, stating that it gives students the idea that university authorities are always divinely inspired and never to be contradicted.{{cite web| last = Waterman| first = Bryan| coauthors = Brian Kagel| title = The Lord's University:Freedom and Authority at BYU | publisher = Signature Books| url = http://www.signaturebooks.com/lords.htm| accessdate = 2008-02-26|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080211185851/http://www.signaturebooks.com/lords.htm |archivedate = February 11, 2008|deadurl=yes}} Leaders of the school, however, acknowledge that the nickname represents more a goal that the university strives for, and not its current state of being. Leaders encourage students and faculty to help fulfill the goal by following the teachings of their religion, adhering to the school's honor code, and serving others with the knowledge they gain while attending.{{cite web| last = Eyring| first = Henry B. | title = A Consecrated Place| work = BYU Speeches| publisher = BYU| url = http://speeches.byu.edu/reader/reader.php?id=836| accessdate = 2008-01-21}}{{cite web| last = Oaks| first = Dallin H.| title = The Formula for Success at BYU| work = BYU Speeches| publisher = BYU| date = 1979-09-11| url = http://speeches.byu.edu/reader/reader.php?id=6736| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} BYU mandates that its students who are members of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] be religiously active.{{cite web| url = http://honorcode.byu.edu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3585&Itemid=4643| title = The Honor Code | accessdate = 2007-05-06 | author = Brigham Young University| quote = Participate regularly in church services}} Both LDS and Non-LDS students are required to provide an endorsement from an ecclesiastic leader with their application for admittance.{{cite web| url = http://honorcode.byu.edu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3584&Itemid=4641| title = Continuing Student Ecclesiastical Endorsement | accessdate = 2007-05-06 | author = Brigham Young University}} Over 900 rooms on BYU campus are used for the purposes of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] congregations. More than 150 congregations meet on BYU campus each Sunday. "BYU's campus becomes one of the busiest and largest centers of worship in the world" with about 24,000 persons attending church services on campus. Some 97% of male BYU graduates and 32% of female graduates took a hiatus from their undergraduate studies at one point to serve as [[Mormon missionary|LDS missionaries]]. Male students typically go on their missions shortly after turning 19 years old. This often occurs during or at the end of their freshman year. Female students may begin their missionary service anytime after turning 21. For males, a full-time mission is two years in length, and for females it lasts 18 months.{{cite web| title = Brigham Young University Reaffirmation of Accreditation 2006 Executive Summary| publisher = BYU| year = 2006| url = http://accredit.byu.edu/resources/selfstudy/Executive_Summary.pdf?lms=23| accessdate = 2008-01-21|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070612020727/http://accredit.byu.edu/resources/selfstudy/Executive_Summary.pdf?lms=23 |archivedate = June 12, 2007|deadurl=yes}} === Honor code === {{Main|Brigham Young University Honor Code}} {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 25%;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: left;" | "As a matter of personal commitment, faculty, administration, staff, and students of Brigham Young University, Brigham Young UniversityâHawaii, Brigham Young UniversityâIdaho, and LDS Business College seek to demonstrate in daily living on and off campus those moral virtues encompassed in the gospel of Jesus Christ, and will * Be honest * Live a chaste and virtuous life * Obey the law and all campus policies * Use clean language * Respect others * Abstain from alcoholic beverages, tobacco, tea, coffee, and substance abuse * Participate regularly in church services * Observe the Dress and Grooming Standards * Encourage others in their commitment to comply with the Honor Code" |- | style="text-align: left;" | â BYU Honor Code Statement |} All students and faculty, regardless of religion, are required to agree to adhere to an [[honor code]]. Early forms of the BYU Honor Code are found as far back as the days of the Brigham Young Academy and early school President Karl G. Maeser. Maeser created the "Domestic Organization", which was a group of teachers who would visit students at their homes to see that they were following the schools moral rules prohibiting obscenity, profanity, smoking, and alcohol consumption. The Honor Code itself was not created until about 1940, and was used mainly for cases of cheating and [[academic dishonesty]]. President Wilkinson expanded the Honor Code in 1957 to include other school standards. This led to what the Honor Code represents today: rules regarding chastity, dress, grooming, drugs, and alcohol. A signed commitment to live the honor code is part of the application process, and must be adhered by all students, faculty, and staff. Students and faculty found in violation of standards are either warned or called to meet with representatives of the Honor Council. In rare cases, students and faculty can be expelled from the school or lose tenure. Both LDS and non-LDS students are required to meet annually with a Church leader to receive an ecclesiastical endorsement for both acceptance and continuance.{{cite web| last = Bergera| first = Gary James | coauthors = Ronald Priddis| title = Chapter 3: Standards & the Honor Code| work = Brigham Young University: A House of Faith| publisher = Signature Books| year = 1985| url = http://www.signaturebookslibrary.org/byu/chapter3.htm| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} Various [[LGBT]] advocacy groups have protested the honor code and criticized it as being [[gay rights opposition|anti-gay]].[http://www.heartstrong.org/HeartStrong/BYU.html "BYU Continues the Legacy of Anti-Gay Policies"], ''HeartStrong''.[http://www.affirmation.org/learning/byu.shtml "Brigham Young University Pages"], ''Affirmation: Gay and Lesbian Mormons''.[http://www.soulforce.org/article/1124 "The 2006 Equality Ride Route: Brigham Young University"], ''Soulforce''. === Culture and activities === [[File:Gordon B. Hinckley Alumni and Visitors Center.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Gordon B. Hinckley Alumni and Visitors Center]]]] BYU's social and cultural atmosphere is unique. The high rate of enrollment at the university by members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints results in an amplification of LDS cultural norms; BYU was ranked by ''The Princeton Review'' in 2008 as 14th in the nation for having the happiest students and highest quality of life.{{cite web| title = 2008 Best 366 Colleges Rankings| publisher = The Princeton Review| year = 2008| url = http://www.princetonreview.com/college/research/rankings/rankingDetailspr07.asp?categoryID=6&topicID=43| accessdate = 2008-01-21|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080315163144/http://www.princetonreview.com/college/research/rankings/rankingDetailspr07.asp?categoryID=6&topicID=43 |archivedate = March 15, 2008|deadurl=yes}} However, the quirkiness and sometimes "too nice" culture is often caricatured, for example, in terms of marrying early and being very conservative. One of the characteristics of BYU most often pointed out is its reputation for emphasizing a [[Dating and marriage at byu|"marriage culture."]]{{cite web| title = Study focuses on BYU marriage perceptions| work = Daily Universe| publisher = BYU| date = 2005-04-29| url = http://nn.byu.edu/story.cfm/55351| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} Members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints highly value marriage and family, especially marriage within the faith.{{cite web| last = Clark| first = Natalie | title = BYU marriage rates higher than national average | work = Daily Universe| publisher = BYU| date = 2005-10-03| url = http://nn.byu.edu/story.cfm/56823| accessdate = 2008-01-21}} Approximately 51% of the graduates in BYU's class of 2005 were married. This is compared to a national marriage average among college graduates of 11%. BYU students on average marry at the age of 22, according to a 2005 study, while the national average age is 25 years for men and 27 years for women. Many visitors to BYU, and Utah Valley as a whole, report being surprised by the culturally conservative environment. Brigham Young University's Honor Code, which all BYU students agree to follow as a condition of studying at BYU, prohibits the consumption of alcoholic beverages, tobacco, etc. As mentioned earlier, The [[Princeton Review]] has rated BYU the "#1 stone cold sober school" in the nation for several years running, an honor which the late LDS Church president [[Gordon B. Hinckley]] had commented on with pride. BYU's 2010 "#1 stone cold" sober rating marked the 12th year in a row that the school had earned that rating. BYU has used this and other honors awarded to the school to advertise itself to prospective students, showing that BYU is proud of the rating. According to the [[Uniform Crime Reports]], incidents of crime in Provo are lower than the national average. Murder is rare, and robberies are about 1/10 the national average.{{cite web|title=Provo UT Crime Statistics (2006 Crime Data)|publisher=Areaconnect.com|url=http://provo.areaconnect.com/crime1.htm|accessdate=2008-01-21}} Many on-campus student activities and clubs are organized by [[BYUSA]], the university's official student association.
